results.title: Moving story
results.brief_description: Provides a brief history of trades shipping in Australia and goes on to outline the function of the Australia to Europe Shipping Conference. The conference comprises eighteen major international shipping companies including the Australian National Line which cooperate to provide a coordinated shipping service for the carriage of Australian exports to Europe at agreed freight rates. Highlights how the merger of technological and management skills can offer efficient service at reasonable rates. Suitable for upper secondary and teacher/tertiary levels.

results.title: Moving pictures: the art of Jan Lenica
results.creator_credit: Richard Rogers, Robert Gardner and Phoenix Films
results.brief_description: Gives insight into the patience, care and concentration that allows Lenica to conquer the processes of animating his pictures. Shows Lenica at work on “Landscapes” at Harvard and explores the relationship of the artist with his “real” world at the moments when he conjures his fantasy visions.

results.title: Moving pictures as text
results.brief_description: This program is designed to develop students’ ability to “read” the moving picture “text” of film, video and television as well as exploring the techniques used by film and television makers.

results.title: Moving pictures
results.creator_credit: Colin Low, Mark Zannis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A multi-layered documentary about the parallels between the mass production of weapons, and the creation and dissemination of mass media images of war and violence. At the same time it is an autobiography of Canadian director and producer Colin Low (who narrates and directs the film) who, over the course of fifty years has worked on over two hundred films. Over this period Low has also massed a large collection of etchings and woodcuts of war. Through these haunting artworks, the fine details of which he has captured through special filming techniques, Low meditates on his growing awareness of war and the perversion of art into propaganda that supports the production of ever more effective weapons of mass destruction.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Low, Mark Zannis and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Moving Out
results.brief_description: Being a teenager can be hard enough. Being an Italian teenager in a very Australian suburb can be impossible! Gino wants to be Australian. After all, we’re all new Aussies, some are just newer than others. Gino doesn’t give up and when he has finally won the friendship of his Australian mates, it’s time to move out!

results.title: Moving out
results.creator_credit: John Moore, Trevor Graham and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: This program is designed to assist people with an intellectual disability who live in institutions to decide whether or not to live in the community. Doug Pentland and Dot Scanlon who have moved into the community, and John Sposito and Robert Dobbins who are preparing to leave an institution discuss some of the difficult issues they face and things people with an intellectual disability need to know about living in the community.

results.title: Moving on
results.creator_credit: Richard Mason, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A drama on the crisis in the Australian rural economy in the early 1970s. Created from a variety of true case histories, the film tells the story of a family faced with near bankruptcy after several seasons of drought and falling prices - and the prospect of moving to the city and a new way of life. Director of Photography: Dean Semler.

results.title: Moving mountains (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Tell the story of women in the coal mining town of Elkford, British Columbia and their attempts to get manual jobs in the open-pit coal mine. Many talk about their initial shyness and the pressure they felt to prove themselves on the trucks and bulldozers. A useful resource to aid discussion and analysis of the changing role of women in the workplace - particularly in relation to non-traditional roles.

results.title: Moving millions
results.creator_credit: Noel Arthur, John Taylor, Central Office of Information and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows how the London transport system handles the millions of yearly passengers. Much of the film deals with behind-the-scenes activities such as the washing and overhaul of vehicles, the training of drivers and conductors, and the testing of new safety devices. Music by Lambert Williamson.

results.title: Moving in = Firstborn
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted, Ron Koslow, Tony Thomas, Paul Junger Witt, Thomas Productions, Witt, Jaffe-Lansing Productions and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: A story of relationships, love, loyalty and family - and intruders who upset the balance. Wendy (Teri Garr) is a young divorced mother with two sons, Jake (Christopher Collet) and Brian (Corey Haim). Mother and sons appear to cope reasonably well in their relationships towards one another with the usual generational disagreements and ups and downs all families face at one time or another. However, when Sam (Peter Weller) enters into Wendy’s life, the boys find themselves gradually being pushed aside as their mother’s interest in Sam turns increasingly to love. When Sam moves in, both Jake and Brian become suspicious of his motives and eventually it is up to Jake, as first born, to try and take control of a situation that is rapidly getting out of hand. Both boys are determined to protect their mother at all costs but for Jake it is a moment of confrontation and making choices. Contains some violent scenes. Cast also includes a very young Sarah Jessica Parker as Jake’s girlfriend, Lisa and Robert Downey Jr (also in his teens) as one of Jake’s friends, Lee.
